message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Benchmarking Intersectional Biases in NLP
Paper Abstract: There has been a recent wave of work assessing the fairness of machine learning models in general, and more specifically, on natural language processing (NLP) models built using machine learning techniques. While much work has highlighted biases embedded in state-of-the-art language models, and more recent efforts have focused on how to debias, research assessing the fairness and performance of biased/debiased models on downstream prediction tasks has been limited. Moreover, most prior work has emphasized bias along a single dimension such as gender or race. In this work, we benchmark multiple NLP models with regards to their fairness and predictive performance across a variety of NLP tasks. In particular, we assess intersectional bias - fairness across multiple demographic dimensions. The results show that while current debiasing strategies fare well in terms of the fairness-accuracy trade-off (generally preserving predictive power in debiased models), they are unable to effectively alleviate bias in downstream tasks. Furthermore, this bias is often amplified across demographic dimensions. We conclude with implications for future NLP debiasing research. © 2022 Association for Computational Linguistics.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here's a comprehensive overview of Natural Language Processing based on the search results:

## Definition and Overview

Natural language processing (NLP) is the processing of natural language information by a computer, and is a subfield of computer science closely associated with artificial intelligence.(no content)NLP is also related to information retrieval, knowledge representation, computational linguistics, and linguistics more broadly.

## Major Tasks

Major processing tasks in an NLP system include: speech recognition, text classification, natural language understanding, and natural language generation.

## Historical Development

Natural language processing has its roots in the 1950s.(no content)Up until the 1980s, most natural language processing systems were based on complex sets of hand-written rules. Starting in the late 1980s, however, there was a revolution in natural language processing with the introduction of machine learning algorithms for language processing.(no content)The concept of large language model (LLM) emerged in late 2010s, with LLM being a language model trained with self-supervised learning on vast amount of text.(no content)In recent years, advancements in deep learning and large language models have significantly enhanced the capabilities of natural language processing, leading to widespread applications in areas such as healthcare, customer service, and content generation.

I've completed a web search for "Machine learning". Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Machine learning (ML) is a field of study in artificial intelligence concerned with the development and study of statistical algorithms that can learn from data and generalise to unseen data, and thus perform tasks without explicit instructions.

## Key Characteristics

Machine learning is commonly separated into three main learning paradigms, supervised learning, unsupervised learning and reinforcement learning.(no content)ML finds application in many fields, including natural language processing, computer vision, speech recognition, email filtering, agriculture, and medicine.

## Historical Development

The term machine learning was coined in 1959 by Arthur Samuel, an IBM employee and pioneer in the field of computer gaming and artificial intelligence.(no content)The earliest machine learning program was introduced in the 1950s when Arthur Samuel invented a computer program that calculated the winning chance in checkers for each side.

## Neural Networks

In machine learning, a neural network or neural net (NN), also called artificial neural network (ANN), is a computational model inspired by the structure and functions of biological neural networks. A neural network consists of connected units or nodes called artificial neurons, which loosely model the neurons in the brain.

The search results show that machine learning has evolved significantly from its origins in the 1950s to become a fundamental technology driving modern artificial intelligence applications.

Here are the search results for "Gender bias":

## Definition and Overview

Gender bias is the tendency to prefer one gender over another.(no content)It is a form of unconscious bias, or implicit bias, which occurs when one individual unconsciously attributes certain attitudes and stereotypes to another person or group of people.(no content)Gender bias and sexism are related but distinct concepts. Sexism is prejudice or discrimination based on sex, often favoring one sex over another. Gender bias is a broader term referring to any bias based on gender.(no content)It can affect anyone, including men, women, and those who don't conform to traditional gender norms.

## Areas Where Gender Bias Occurs

**Education:** Gender bias in teachers' grading refers to systematic differences in the grades assigned to male and female students that cannot be explained by actual differences in performance. A gender grading gap occurs when teachers assign different grades to boys and girls who demonstrate equivalent levels of academic performance.

**Healthcare:** Gender-biased diagnosing is the idea that medical and psychological diagnosis are influenced by the patient's gender. Several studies have found evidence of differential diagnosis for patients with similar ailments but of different sexes.

**Workplace:** Second-generation gender bias is a form of gender bias that appears neutral or not overtly sexist, but which discriminates against women because it reflects the values of the men who created or developed the setting, usually a workplace.

**Media and Advertising:** Gender in advertising refers to the images and concepts in advertising that depict and reinforce stereotypical gender roles.

Links: [{"title":"Gender bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gender_bias"},{"title":"Second-generation gender bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second-generation_gender_bias"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Gender bias and editing on Wikipedia - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Gender_bias_and_editing_on_Wikipedia"},{"title":"Gender bias on Wikipedia - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gender_bias_on_Wikipedia"},{"title":"Gender bias in medical diagnosis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gender_bias_in_medical_diagnosis"},{"title":"Media and gender - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Media_and_gender"},{"title":"Discrimination against men - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrimination_against_men"},{"title":"Sex differences in intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sex_differences_in_intelligence"},{"title":"Talk:Unisex public toilet - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Gender-neutral_toilet"},{"title":"Gender in advertising - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gender_in_advertising"}]

Here are the search results for "Gender bias":

## Definition and Overview

Gender bias is the tendency to prefer one gender over another.(no content)It is a form of unconscious bias, or implicit bias, which occurs when one individual unconsciously attributes certain attitudes and stereotypes to another person or group of people.(no content)Gender bias and sexism are related but distinct concepts. Sexism is prejudice or discrimination based on sex, often favoring one sex over another. Gender bias is a broader term referring to any bias based on gender.(no content)It can affect anyone, including men, women, and those who don't conform to traditional gender norms.

## Areas Where Gender Bias Occurs

**Education:** Gender bias in teachers' grading refers to systematic differences in the grades assigned to male and female students that cannot be explained by actual differences in performance. A gender grading gap occurs when teachers assign different grades to boys and girls who demonstrate equivalent levels of academic performance.

**Healthcare:** Gender-biased diagnosing is the idea that medical and psychological diagnosis are influenced by the patient's gender. Several studies have found evidence of differential diagnosis for patients with similar ailments but of different sexes.

**Workplace:** Second-generation gender bias is a form of gender bias that appears neutral or not overtly sexist, but which discriminates against women because it reflects the values of the men who created or developed the setting, usually a workplace.

**Media and Advertising:** Gender in advertising refers to the images and concepts in advertising that depict and reinforce stereotypical gender roles.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Intersectionality"

Links: [{"title":"Intersectionality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intersectionality"},{"title":"Violence and intersectionality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Violence_and_intersectionality"},{"title":"Vegetarian ecofeminism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vegetarian_ecofeminism"},{"title":"Peter Hopkins (geographer) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Hopkins_(geographer)"},{"title":"Sexual assault of LGBTQ persons - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sexual_assault_of_LGBTQ_persons"},{"title":"Matrix of domination - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matrix_of_domination"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of intersectionality based on the search results:

## Definition and Core Concept

Intersectionality is an analytical framework for understanding how groups' and individuals' social and political identities result in unique combinations of discrimination and privilege.(no content)While many readers understand intersectionality as the overlapping of multiple social identities (such as race, gender, and class), the original intent was to provide an internal framework for analyzing systems of oppression and privilege that interlock.

## Origins

The term intersectionality was coined by Kimberlé Crenshaw in 1989.(no content)Crenshaw introduced the concept in a pair of essays published in 1989 and 1991, within the subject of legal studies.(no content)Intersectionality arose in reaction to both white feminism and the then male-dominated Black liberation movement, citing the "interlocking oppressions" of racism, sexism and heteronormativity.

## Key Aspects

Examples of intersecting and overlapping factors include gender, caste, sex, race, ethnicity, class, sexuality, religion, disability, physical appearance, and age.(no content)Discrimination against black women cannot be explained as a simple combination of misogyny and racism, but as something more complicated.

## Contemporary Impact and Criticism

Intersectionality has heavily influenced modern feminism and gender studies. However, critics suggest that the concept is too broad or complex, tends to reduce individuals to specific demographic factors, is used as an ideological tool, and is difficult to apply in research contexts.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Fairness in machine learning"

Links: [{"title":"Fairness (machine learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fairness_(machine_learning)"},{"title":"Equalized odds - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equalized_odds"},{"title":"Ethics of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethics_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Hanna Wallach - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hanna_Wallach"},{"title":"Rayid Ghani - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rayid_Ghani"},{"title":"Fairness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fairness"},{"title":"Automated decision-making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_decision-making"},{"title":"Algorithmic bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bias_in_machine_learning"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_engineering"},{"title":"Maximin share - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maximin_share"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about fairness in machine learning:

## Definition and Overview

Fairness in machine learning refers to the various attempts to correct algorithmic bias in automated decision processes based on ML models.(no content)Decisions made by such models may be considered unfair if they were based on variables considered sensitive, such as gender, ethnicity, sexual orientation, or disability.

## Key Challenges

There is no universal definition of fairness, and different definitions can be in contradiction with each other, which makes it difficult to judge machine learning models. For example, defining fairness as "equality of outcomes" may refer to a system producing the same result for all people, while fairness defined as "equality of treatment" might explicitly consider differences between individuals.

## Real-World Examples of Bias

Several documented cases illustrate fairness issues in machine learning:
- Amazon used software to review job applications that was sexist, for example by penalizing resumes that included the word "women".
- In 2019, Apple's algorithm to determine credit card limits gave significantly higher limits to males than females.
- Mortgage-approval algorithms in the U.S. were shown to be more likely to reject non-white applicants.

## Industry Response

In recent years tech companies have made tools and manuals on how to detect and reduce bias. IBM has tools for Python and R with algorithms to reduce software bias, and Google has published guidelines and tools to study and combat bias in machine learning.

## Research Development

Since 2016 there has been a sharp increase in research into the topic, partly attributed to an influential report by ProPublica claiming that the COMPAS software, widely used in US courts to predict recidivism, was racially biased.

Web search results for query: "Racial bias"

Links: [{"title":"Racial bias in criminal news in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Racial_bias_in_criminal_news_in_the_United_States"},{"title":"Racial bias on Wikipedia - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Racial_bias_on_Wikipedia"},{"title":"Accusations of racial bias in Grammy Awards - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accusations_of_racial_bias_in_Grammy_Awards"},{"title":"Shooting bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shooting_bias"},{"title":"Racial stereotyping in advertising - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Racial_stereotyping_in_advertising"},{"title":"Algorithmic bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algorithmic_bias"},{"title":"Wikipedia:WikiProject Countering systemic bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:WikiProject_Countering_systemic_bias"},{"title":"Racial-ethnic socialization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Racial-ethnic_socialization"},{"title":"Racism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Racism"},{"title":"Racism in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Racism_in_the_United_States"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of racial bias:

## Definition and Nature

Racial biases are a form of implicit bias, which refers to the attitudes or stereotypes that affect an individual's understanding, actions, and decisions in an unconscious manner.(no content)These biases, which encompass unfavorable assessments, are often activated involuntarily and without the awareness or intentional control of the individual, residing deep in the subconscious.

## Areas Where Racial Bias Appears

Racial bias manifests across various domains:

- **Media and News**: Racial bias has been recorded in criminal news reporting from the United States, particularly with regard to African American individuals, and a perceived fear of African Americans among European and White Americans.

- **Algorithmic and AI Systems**: Racial bias refers to the tendency of machine learning models to produce outcomes that unfairly discriminate against or stereotype individuals based on race or ethnicity, often stemming from training data shaped by humans' opinions, assumptions, and racial prejudices.

- **Advertising**: Racial stereotyping in advertising refers to using assumptions about people based on characteristics thought to be typical of their identifying racial group in marketing.

- **Law Enforcement**: Police officers have been found to show a racial bias against black people in the decision to shoot, and implicit biases are directly correlated with shooting behavior.

- **Healthcare**: There are major racial differences in access to health care as well as major racial differences in the quality of the health care provided to people.

- **Employment**: A 2016 meta-analysis of 738 correspondence tests in 43 separate studies conducted in OECD countries between 1990 and 2015 finds that there is extensive racial discrimination in hiring decisions in Europe and North America, showing that equivalent minority candidates need to send around 50% more applications to be invited for an interview than majority candidates.

Links: [{"title":"Racial bias in criminal news in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Racial_bias_in_criminal_news_in_the_United_States"},{"title":"Racial bias on Wikipedia - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Racial_bias_on_Wikipedia"},{"title":"Accusations of racial bias in Grammy Awards - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accusations_of_racial_bias_in_Grammy_Awards"},{"title":"Shooting bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shooting_bias"},{"title":"Racial stereotyping in advertising - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Racial_stereotyping_in_advertising"},{"title":"Algorithmic bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algorithmic_bias"},{"title":"Wikipedia:WikiProject Countering systemic bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:WikiProject_Countering_systemic_bias"},{"title":"Racial-ethnic socialization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Racial-ethnic_socialization"},{"title":"Racism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Racism"},{"title":"Racism in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Racism_in_the_United_States"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of racial bias:

## Definition and Nature

Racial biases are a form of implicit bias, which refers to the attitudes or stereotypes that affect an individual's understanding, actions, and decisions in an unconscious manner.(no content)These biases, which encompass unfavorable assessments, are often activated involuntarily and without the awareness or intentional control of the individual, residing deep in the subconscious.

## Areas Where Racial Bias Appears

Racial bias manifests across various domains:

- **Media and News**: Racial bias has been recorded in criminal news reporting from the United States, particularly with regard to African American individuals, and a perceived fear of African Americans among European and White Americans.

- **Algorithmic and AI Systems**: Racial bias refers to the tendency of machine learning models to produce outcomes that unfairly discriminate against or stereotype individuals based on race or ethnicity, often stemming from training data shaped by humans' opinions, assumptions, and racial prejudices.

- **Advertising**: Racial stereotyping in advertising refers to using assumptions about people based on characteristics thought to be typical of their identifying racial group in marketing.

- **Law Enforcement**: Police officers have been found to show a racial bias against black people in the decision to shoot, and implicit biases are directly correlated with shooting behavior.

- **Healthcare**: There are major racial differences in access to health care as well as major racial differences in the quality of the health care provided to people.

- **Employment**: A 2016 meta-analysis of 738 correspondence tests in 43 separate studies conducted in OECD countries between 1990 and 2015 finds that there is extensive racial discrimination in hiring decisions in Europe and North America, showing that equivalent minority candidates need to send around 50% more applications to be invited for an interview than majority candidates.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Algorithmic bias"

Links: [{"title":"Algorithmic bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algorithmic_bias"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Featured article candidates/Algorithmic bias/archive1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Featured_article_candidates/Algorithmic_bias/archive1"},{"title":"Joy Buolamwini - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joy_Buolamwini"},{"title":"Fairness (machine learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fairness_(machine_learning)"},{"title":"Representational harm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Representational_harm"},{"title":"Abeba Birhane - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abeba_Birhane"},{"title":"Coded Bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coded_Bias"},{"title":"Algorithm aversion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algorithm_aversion"},{"title":"Bias–variance tradeoff","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bias–variance_tradeoff"},{"title":"Algorithms of Oppression - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algorithms_of_Oppression"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of algorithmic bias:

## Definition and Scope

Algorithmic bias describes systematic and repeatable errors that create unfair outcomes, such as privileging one arbitrary group of users over others.(no content)Bias can emerge from many factors, including but not limited to the design of the algorithm or the unintended or unanticipated use or decisions relating to the way data is coded, collected, selected or used to train the algorithm.

## Sources and Causes

Bias can enter into algorithmic systems as a result of pre-existing cultural, social, or institutional expectations; by how features and labels are chosen; because of technical limitations of their design; or by being used in unanticipated contexts or by audiences who are not considered in the software's initial design.

## Real-World Impact

Algorithmic bias has been documented across multiple domains:

- **Facial Recognition**: The relative inability of facial recognition technology to accurately identify darker-skinned faces has been linked to multiple wrongful arrests of black men, an issue stemming from imbalanced datasets.

- **Criminal Justice**: The 2016 report by ProPublica on COMPAS claimed that black defendants were almost twice as likely to be incorrectly labelled as higher risk than white defendants, while making the opposite mistake with white defendants.

- **Hiring and Finance**: Amazon has used software to review job applications that was sexist, for example by penalizing resumes that included the word "women". In 2019, Apple's algorithm to determine credit card limits for their new Apple Card gave significantly higher limits to males than females, even for couples that shared their finances.(no content)Algorithmic bias has also arisen in criminal justice, healthcare, and hiring, compounding existing racial, socioeconomic, and gender biases.

## Challenges in Detection and Resolution

Problems in understanding, researching, and discovering algorithmic bias persist due to the proprietary nature of algorithms, which are typically treated as trade secrets.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Language model"

Links: [{"title":"Small language model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Small_language_model"},{"title":"List of large language models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_large_language_models"},{"title":"Language model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language_model"},{"title":"Large language model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_language_model"},{"title":"Usage-based models of language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usage-based_models_of_language"},{"title":"Llama (language model) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LLaMA"},{"title":"BERT (language model) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BERT_(Language_model)"},{"title":"Vision-language-action model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vision-language-action_model"},{"title":"PaLM - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PaLM"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Large language models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Large_language_models"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of language models:

## Definition

A language model is a model of the human brain's ability to produce natural language.(no content)Language models are useful for a variety of tasks, including speech recognition, machine translation, natural language generation (generating more human-like text), optical character recognition, route optimization, handwriting recognition, grammar induction, and information retrieval.

## Large Language Models (LLMs)

A large language model (LLM) is a language model trained with self-supervised machine learning on a vast amount of text, designed for natural language processing tasks, especially language generation.(no content)They consist of billions to trillions of parameters and operate as general-purpose sequence models, generating, summarizing, translating, and reasoning over text.(no content)LLMs represent a significant new technology in their ability to generalize across tasks with minimal task-specific supervision, enabling capabilities like conversational agents, code generation, knowledge retrieval, and automated reasoning that previously required bespoke systems.

## Evolution and Architecture

The transformer architecture, introduced in 2017, replaced recurrence with self-attention, allowing efficient parallelization, longer context handling, and scalable training on unprecedented data volumes.(no content)The largest and most capable LLMs are generative pre-trained transformers (GPTs) and provide the core capabilities of modern chatbots.

## Small Language Models

Small language models or compact language models are artificial intelligence language models designed for human natural language processing including language and text generation.(no content)Small language models use far fewer parameters, typically ranging from a few thousand to a few hundred million, making them more feasible to train and host in resource-constrained environments such as a single computer or even a mobile device.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

A large language model (LLM) is a language model trained with self-supervised machine learning on a vast amount of text, designed for natural language processing tasks, especially language generation.(no content)They consist of billions to trillions of parameters and operate as general-purpose sequence models, generating, summarizing, translating, and reasoning over text.(no content)LLMs represent a significant new technology in their ability to generalize across tasks with minimal task-specific supervision, enabling capabilities like conversational agents, code generation, knowledge retrieval, and automated reasoning that previously required bespoke systems.

## Evolution and Architecture

The transformer architecture, introduced in 2017, replaced recurrence with self-attention, allowing efficient parallelization, longer context handling, and scalable training on unprecedented data volumes.(no content)The largest and most capable LLMs are generative pre-trained transformers (GPTs) and provide the core capabilities of modern chatbots.

## Small Language Models

Small language models or compact language models are artificial intelligence language models designed for human natural language processing including language and text generation.(no content)Small language models use far fewer parameters, typically ranging from a few thousand to a few hundred million, making them more feasible to train and host in resource-constrained environments such as a single computer or even a mobile device.

Perfect! I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Benchmarking Intersectional Biases in NLP". Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification:** Contribution (proposes a new benchmark and evaluation methodology)

**Key Entities Identified:** 8 triples extracted from the paper's title and abstract

**Triples Added:**
1. **Natural language processing** (concept) - uses
2. **Machine learning** (concept) - uses
3. **Fairness (machine learning)** (concept) - uses
4. **Algorithmic bias** (concept) - uses
5. **Gender bias** (concept) - uses
6. **Racism** (concept) - uses
7. **Intersectionality** (concept) - proposes ✨
8. **Language model** (artifact) - uses

**Validation Status:** ✅ PASSED

All requirements were met:
- The paper has at least 1 "uses" triple (it has 7)
- The contribution paper has at least 1 "proposes" triple (intersectionality as the novel framework)
- All Wikipedia URLs are valid and verified
- Each triple includes relevant context explaining its significance

The paper's novel contribution is the application of the intersectionality framework to NLP model evaluation, showing how biases across multiple demographic dimensions interact and amplify in downstream NLP tasks.

Sources:
- [Natural language processing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_language_processing)
